articles.headline: African Crucible: Cast as Witches, Then Cast Out
articles.snippet: A surprising number of children in some countries are identified as witches and beaten, abused or abandoned.
articles.abstract: A surprising number of children in some countries are identified as witches and beaten, abused or abandoned.
articles.lead_paragraph: UIGE, Angola — Domingos Pedro was only 12 years old when his father died. The passing was sudden; the cause was a mystery to doctors. But not to Domingos’s relatives.

articles.headline: Foreclosures Hit a Snag for Lenders
articles.snippet: A federal judge in Ohio has ruled against a longstanding foreclosure practice, potentially creating an obstacle for lenders trying to reclaim properties from troubled borrowers.
articles.abstract: A federal judge in Ohio has ruled against a longstanding foreclosure practice, potentially creating an obstacle for lenders trying to reclaim properties from troubled borrowers.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Ohio has ruled against a longstanding foreclosure practice, potentially creating an obstacle for lenders trying to reclaim properties from troubled borrowers and raising questions about the legal standing of investors in mortgage securities pools.

articles.headline: In Eco-Friendly Factory, Low-Guilt Potato Chips
articles.snippet: Frito-Lay is redesigning a potato-chip factory aiming to reduce the energy it consumes and waste it creates.
articles.abstract: Frito-Lay is redesigning a potato-chip factory aiming to reduce the energy it consumes and waste it creates.
articles.lead_paragraph: CASA GRANDE, Ariz. — At Frito-Lay’s factory here, more than 500,000 pounds of potatoes arrive every day from New Mexico to be washed, sliced, fried, seasoned and portioned into bags of Lay’s and Ruffles chips. The process devours enormous amounts of energy, and creates vast amounts of wastewater, starch and potato peelings.

articles.headline: Romney, Searching and Earnest, Set His Path in ’60s
articles.snippet: A six-year immersion in the Mormon Church, including a mission in France, set the conservative course Mitt Romney would follow as a businessman and politician.
articles.abstract: A six-year immersion in the Mormon Church, including a mission in France, set the conservative course Mitt Romney would follow as a businessman and politician.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 — In December 1968, Mitt Romney returned home from a Mormon mission in France to find a changed country.

articles.headline: Rumors, Merger Talk and Denial by Airlines
articles.snippet: After a letter from a hedge fund stoked rumors that it was in merger talks with UAL, Delta Air Lines denied that any such discussions were taking place.
articles.abstract: After a letter from a hedge fund stoked rumors that it was in merger talks with UAL, Delta Air Lines denied that any such discussions were taking place.
articles.lead_paragraph: Long-simmering talk of an inevitable round of airline industry mergers heated up again yesterday. By the end of the day, after a spike in their share prices, the central players in any merger talks, dismissed the rumors as just that.

articles.headline: Fed to Share More of Its Thinking in Its Reports
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve said that it would take some of the mystery out of its decision-making, disclosing far more information about its economic forecasts.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve said that it would take some of the mystery out of its decision-making, disclosing far more information about its economic forecasts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 — The Federal Reserve said Wednesday that it would take some of the mystery out of its decision-making, disclosing far more information about its economic forecasts — and, implicitly, about its objectives for growth and inflation.

articles.headline: Goldman’s Shadow Extends Far Past Wall St.
articles.snippet: For decades, Goldman Sachs has churned out a golden list of corporate executives and statesmen, wealthy financiers and nonprofit managers.
articles.abstract: For decades, Goldman Sachs has churned out a golden list of corporate executives and statesmen, wealthy financiers and nonprofit managers.
articles.lead_paragraph: As John A. Thain prepares to take the reins of Merrill Lynch, he is only the latest example of a tradition borne out across Wall Street, in Washington and around the world. He is a Goldman Sachs alumnus who has reached the top elsewhere.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Airlines Work on Systems to Reduce Delays
articles.snippet: Improvement in airline tracking software could mean fewer stranded travelers and less frequent delays.
articles.abstract: Improvement in airline tracking software could mean fewer stranded travelers and less frequent delays.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT WORTH — At any given moment, the airline industry’s powerful networks of computers are setting fares, tracking reservations and calculating how much fuel each plane needs to reach its destination.

articles.headline: NYSE Chief Is Chosen to Lead Merrill Lynch
articles.snippet: John A. Thain, a former co-president of Goldman Sachs, revitalized the stock exchange and took it public.
articles.abstract: John A. Thain, a former co-president of Goldman Sachs, revitalized the stock exchange and took it public.
articles.lead_paragraph: John A. Thain won plaudits as Wall Street’s Mr. Fix-It by revitalizing the embattled New York Stock Exchange. Now, he faces what could be a more formidable challenge: turning around Merrill Lynch, the once-proud Wall Street firm battered by losses from the mortgage debacle.
articles.byline: By Jenny Anderson and Landon Thomas Jr
